revision.text:
{{infobox UK place| |country = Wales |welsh_name=Llangamarch |constituency_welsh_assembly=[[Brecon and Radnorshire (National Assembly for Wales constituency)|Brecon & Radnorshire]] |map_type= |population= 475 |official_name= Llangammarch Wells |static_image=[[Image:Cammarch Hotel, Llangammarch Wells in 2006.jpg|250px]] |static_image_caption=Cammarch Hotel, Llangammarch Wells |unitary_wales= [[Powys]] |lieutenancy_wales= [[Powys]] |constituency_westminster= [[Brecon & Radnorshire (UK Parliament constituency)|Brecon & Radnorshire]] |post_town= LLANGAMMARCH WELLS |postcode_district = LD4 |postcode_area= LD |dial_code= 01591 |os_grid_reference= SN934473 }}
'''Llangammarch Wells''' or simply '''Llangammarch''' ({{lang-cy|Llangamarch}}) is a [[village]] in the parish of [[Llangammarch]] in [[Powys]], within the [[Historic counties of Wales|historic boundaries]] of [[Brecknockshire]], mid [[Wales]], lying on the [[Afon Irfon|River Irfon]].
It is the smallest of the four [[spa town|spa village]]s of [[mid-Wales]], alongside [[Llandrindod Wells]], [[Builth Wells]] and [[Llanwrtyd Wells]]. The spa was focused on a [[barium]] [[water well|well]], which is now closed, but the village is still popular with [[Angling|anglers]]. The old village is centred around the parish church of [[St Cammarch]].
It benefits from a [[railway station]] on the [[Heart of Wales Line]]. It lies on Route 43 of the [[National Cycle Network]].
[[File:Llangammarch Wells Church - geograph.org.uk - 230357.jpg|thumb|250px|Llangammarch Wells Church]]
==External links== *[http://www.wiz.to/llangammarch/ Village website] *[http://www.heart-of-wales.co.uk/llangammarch/llangammarch.htm Further website] *[http://www.geograph.org.uk/search.php?i=5975857 Photos of Llangammarch Wells and surrounding area on geograph] *[http://www.genuki.org.uk/big/wal/BRE/Llangamarch/index.html Llangamarch at genuki.org]

revision.text:
{{Ethnic Omaha (sidebar)}} '''Mexicans in Omaha''' are people living in [[Omaha, Nebraska]], [[United States]] who have citizenship or [[ancestry|ancestral]] connections to the country [[Mexico]]. They have contributed to the economic, social and cultural well-being of Omaha for more than a century. Mexicans, or [[Latino]] people identified incorrectly as being from Mexico, have been accounted for in the [[history of Omaha]], [[Nebraska]] since 1900. The entire Latino population of Omaha increased ninety percent between 1990 and 1997.<ref>Lopez, David A. (2000). [http://www.jsri.msu.edu/RandS/research/cb/cb12.html "Latinos in Omaha: An Examination of Socioeconomic Measures for Latinos in South Omaha."] ''Statistical Brief No. 12''. The Julian Samora Research Institute at Michigan State University.</ref>
Mexican-Americans in Omaha have been extensively studied since at least the late 1920s.<ref>T. Earl Sullenger, (1929) "The Mexican Population of Omaha," ''Journal of Applied Sociology, VIII.'' May–June. p. 289.</ref> In 1998 a Mexican immigrant family in Omaha was featured in a ''[[Washington Post]]'' article. The article noted reluctance by some immigrants to assimilate, in terms of their thinking they had to give up their language or culture. Studies since then have noted that Latino children, like many immigrant children, have adapted more readily to the United States, but also like many immigrant groups, are proud to maintain traditions.
==History== The presence of Mexicans in Omaha was documented to the [[History of Omaha|beginning of the city]] in 1854, and the first permanent residents arrived with the railroads in 1860.<ref>Arbelaez, Maria S. (2000) [http://www.eric.ed.gov/ERICDocs/data/ericdocs2sql/content_storage_01/0000019b/80/17/1c/82.pdf "Good Friday in Omaha, Nebraska: A Mexican Celebration,"] In ''National Association of African American Studies & National Association of Hispanic and Latino Studies 2000 Literature Monograph Series.'' Proceedings (Culture Section) (Houston, TX, February 21–26, 2000). p 9. Retrieved 9/5/07.</ref>
1900 was the beginning of the first large wave of Mexicans immigrating to the U.S.<ref>McWilliams, C. and Meier, M.(1990) ''North from Mexico: The Spanish-Speaking People of the United States.'' . New York: Praeger.</ref> According to the [[University of Nebraska at Omaha]], around 1900, five Mexican-born residents lived in Omaha, and by 1910 there were twenty-nine. In 1920 there were 682 Mexicans in Omaha; in 1923 there were about 1,000. They lived in South Omaha, close to the three packing plants and the stockyards where many worked.<ref>Grajeda, R. (n.d.) [http://www.nebraskahistory.org/lib-arch/whadoin/mexampub/mexicans.htm Mexicans in Nebraska] Nebraska State Historical Society. Retrieved 3/12/07.</ref> In 1950 the population of Mexicans in [[Douglas County, Nebraska|Douglas County]] was 450.<ref>Wheeler, W. (1975) ''An Almanac of Nebraska: Nationality, Ethnic, and Racial Groups.'' Omaha, NE: Park Bromwell Press.</ref> The loss of jobs in the [[Great Depression]] drove many Mexicans back to Mexico, but approximately 900 stayed in Omaha.<ref>Arbelaez, Maria S. (2000) [http://www.eric.ed.gov/ERICDocs/data/ericdocs2sql/content_storage_01/0000019b/80/17/1c/82.pdf "Good Friday in Omaha, Nebraska: A Mexican Celebration,"] In ''National Association of African American Studies & National Association of Hispanic and Latino Studies 2000 Literature Monograph Series.'' Proceedings (Culture Section) (Houston, TX, February 21–26, 2000). p 10. Retrieved 9/5/07.</ref>
===Communities=== In the early decades of the 1900s, Mexican families established themselves in ''[[Colonia (United States)|colonia]]s''<ref>Valdés, D.N. (2000) ''Barrios Nortenos: St. Paul and Midwestern Mexican Communities in the Twentieth Century.'' University of Texas Press. p 33.</ref> next to the [[Chicago, Burlington, and Quincy Railroad]] depot south of [[Little Italy (Omaha, Nebraska)|Little Italy]] and [[Little Bohemia (Omaha, Nebraska)|Little Bohemia]]. The depot was called [[Gibson Station]], and was located at South First and Hascal Streets near the [[Missouri River]].<ref>T. Earl Sullenger, (1929) "The Mexican Population of Omaha," ''Journal of Applied Sociology, VIII.'' May–June. p. 291.</ref> Near South 72nd and Q Streets there was another ''[[barrio]]'' where Mexican families lived in [[railroad car]]s next to the Union Pacific-Santa Fe station. More Mexican families lived among Italian, Polish, Hungarian, and Czech immigrants.<ref>T. Earl Sullenger, (1929) "The Mexican Population of Omaha," ''Journal of Applied Sociology, VIII.'' May–June. p. 287.</ref> Much of the community is said to have lived in the [[Brown Park]] neighborhood, as well.<ref>Thiele, S., Jordan, T.E., Lopez, D.A., et al. (2001) ''The Latino Experience in Omaha.'' E. Mellen Press. p 14.</ref>
Other Mexican communities were near the [[Burlington Train Station]] around South Sixth Street; in [[Omaha, Nebraska|Carville]], near [[Gibson Guitar Corporation|Gibson]] in South Omaha along the [[Missouri River]], "where most lived in railroad cars on Burlington Railroad property", and along Spring Street. J.B. Hernández, a railroad worker, was the acknowledged leader of Carville. His family was viewed as the "aristocrats of Carville".<ref>Valdés, D.N. (2000) ''Barrios Nortenos: St. Paul and Midwestern Mexican Communities in the Twentieth Century.'' University of Texas Press. p 78.</ref>
There was also a large community east of the Missouri River in [[Council Bluffs]]. The largest concentration of Mexicans and Mexican Americans in Omaha lived near the [[packing house]]s and [[Union Stockyards (Omaha)|Union Stockyards]] of South Omaha.<ref>Valdés, D.N. (2000) ''Barrios Nortenos: St. Paul and Midwestern Mexican Communities in the Twentieth Century.'' University of Texas Press. p 33.</ref>
Today the majority of Mexicans and Mexican-Americans live in South Omaha, also called South O. A strong Mexican-American presence thrives there, with numerous public murals and exhibitions of [[Mexican culture]] throughout the community. Along with a variety of businesses, churches and community organizations, the area features [[El Museo Latino]]. It hosts four visits per year of the Mobile Mexican Consultant of Denver.<ref>Arbelaez, Maria S. (2000) [http://www.eric.ed.gov/ERICDocs/data/ericdocs2sql/content_storage_01/0000019b/80/17/1c/82.pdf "Good Friday in Omaha, Nebraska: A Mexican Celebration,"] In ''National Association of African American Studies & National Association of Hispanic and Latino Studies 2000 Literature Monograph Series.'' Proceedings (Culture Section) (Houston, TX, February 21–26, 2000). p 13. Retrieved 9/5/07.</ref> In 1998, the community was estimated to have 20,000 Latino families.<ref>Arbelaez, Maria S. (2000) [http://www.eric.ed.gov/ERICDocs/data/ericdocs2sql/content_storage_01/0000019b/80/17/1c/82.pdf "Good Friday in Omaha, Nebraska: A Mexican Celebration,"] In ''National Association of African American Studies & National Association of Hispanic and Latino Studies 2000 Literature Monograph Series.'' Proceedings (Culture Section) (Houston, TX, February 21–26, 2000). p 20. Retrieved 9/5/07.</ref>
===Workforce=== According to one study about the period 1900–1930, "Early censuses report few Mexicans, and existing statistics are ambiguous. Mostly, Mexicans were accounted as 'floaters,' shifting jobs between meat packing plants, section hands on the railroads, and agricultural laborers..."<ref>Arbelaez, M. (2006) ''[http://www.unomaha.edu/ollas/pdf/Religion%20Report.pdf Religion and Community: Mexican Americans in South Omaha (1900–1980).]'' OLLAS Special Report No. 4. Omaha, NE: Office of Latino/Latin American Studies at the University of Nebraska at Omaha.</ref>
Jobs in [[agriculture]], [[packing house]]s, and [[railroad]]s drew Mexican laborers to Omaha.<ref>T. Earl Sullenger, (1929) "The Mexican Population of Omaha," ''Journal of Applied Sociology, VIII.'' May–June. p. 289.</ref> Shortly after the beginning of [[World War I]], the packing houses and Union Stockyards hired Mexicans as [[strikebreaker]]s during a labor shortage. After the strike broke, several hundred Mexican workers stayed in Omaha.<ref>Larsen, L. & Cotrell, B. (1997). ''The Gate City: A history of Omaha.'' University of Nebraska Press. P 163.</ref> According to the [[Nebraska State Historical Society]], there are a few remaining Mexican elders who came to Omaha through [[Kansas City, Missouri|Kansas City]] as railroad workers for the [[Union Pacific]] and the [[BNSF Railway]]. Across Omaha there "are [[Mexican American]]s whose grandfathers or other male relatives worked as railroad section-hands."<ref>Grajeda, R. (n.d.) [http://www.nebraskahistory.org/lib-arch/whadoin/mexampub/mexicans.htm Mexicans in Nebraska] Nebraska State Historical Society. Retrieved 3/12/07.</ref>
In Omaha in 1924 the average packinghouse paid $3.36 a day,<ref>Valdés, D.N. (2000) ''Barrios Nortenos: St. Paul and Midwestern Mexican Communities in the Twentieth Century.'' University of Texas Press. p 82.</ref> and in 1928 ten railroad companies employed between 800 and 1000 Mexicans in the winter, and less than 250 in the summer.<ref>Valdés, D.N. (2000) ''Barrios Nortenos: St. Paul and Midwestern Mexican Communities in the Twentieth Century.'' University of Texas Press. p 81.</ref> In the 1930s many Mexicans in Omaha traveled back and forth from western Nebraska to work in the agriculture industry.<ref>Arbelaez, Maria S. (2000) [http://www.eric.ed.gov/ERICDocs/data/ericdocs2sql/content_storage_01/0000019b/80/17/1c/82.pdf "Good Friday in Omaha, Nebraska: A Mexican Celebration,"] In ''National Association of African American Studies & National Association of Hispanic and Latino Studies 2000 Literature Monograph Series.'' Proceedings (Culture Section) (Houston, TX, February 21–26, 2000). p 11. Retrieved 9/5/07.</ref>
===Religion=== A Roman Catholic church called Nuestra Señora de Guadalupe was founded in Omaha in 1919.,<ref>Larsen, L. & Cotrell, B. (1997). ''The Gate City: A history of Omaha.'' University of Nebraska Press. P 163.</ref><ref>[http://www.nebraskahistory.org/lib-arch/whadoin/mexampub/reyes.htm "Juvencia Reyes"], Nebraska State Historical Society. Retrieved 9/1/07.</ref> and has been the "main pivot of the Hispanic community in Omaha, the state and neighboring counties in [[Iowa]] across the Missouri River." Its first home was in a rented room above a baker's shop.<ref>Arbelaez, Maria S. (2000) [http://www.eric.ed.gov/ERICDocs/data/ericdocs2sql/content_storage_01/0000019b/80/17/1c/82.pdf "Good Friday in Omaha, Nebraska: A Mexican Celebration,"] In ''National Association of African American Studies & National Association of Hispanic and Latino Studies 2000 Literature Monograph Series.'' Proceedings (Culture Section) (Houston, TX, February 21–26, 2000). p 9. Retrieved 9/5/07.</ref>
During the 1960s both [[Catholic]] and [[Protestant]] congregations encouraged Mexican Americans in Omaha "to move forward with a more proactive role in claiming their identity and place in the community."<ref>Arbelaez, M. (2006) ''[http://www.unomaha.edu/ollas/pdf/Religion%20Report.pdf Religion and Community: Mexican Americans in South Omaha (1900–1980).]'' OLLAS Special Report No. 4. Omaha, NE: Office of Latino/Latin American Studies at the University of Nebraska at Omaha.</ref>
===Crime=== In the 1930s [[Crime in Omaha|crime among Mexican Americans]] ranked "higher than any other immigrant class born in the city." Researchers attributed this to poverty, language barriers, police politics and the lack of political representation.<ref>Valdés, D.N. (2000) ''Barrios Nortenos: St. Paul and Midwestern Mexican Communities in the Twentieth Century.'' University of Texas Press. p 59.</ref> Mexican Americans in Omaha were also the target of [[Racial tension in Omaha, Nebraska|racial tension]], with one period report finding, "at social gatherings of the schools and churches, Mexican children were spat upon and called "[[Greaser (derogatory)|greaser]]s" by other children."<ref>Valdés, D.N. (2000) ''Barrios Nortenos: St. Paul and Midwestern Mexican Communities in the Twentieth Century.'' University of Texas Press. p 63.</ref>
==Present== ===Population=== In the early 1970s a population survey conducted by the Lutheran Ministries of Omaha estimated that there were 6,490 Latinos in Omaha, with two-thirds of the population coming from Mexico.<ref>Arbelaez, M. (2006) ''[http://www.unomaha.edu/ollas/pdf/Religion%20Report.pdf Religion and Community: Mexican Americans in South Omaha (1900–1980).]'' OLLAS Special Report No. 4. Omaha, NE: Office of Latino/Latin American Studies at the University of Nebraska at Omaha.</ref> A 1978 study found that Mexican Americans in Omaha felt particular satisfaction with their lifestyle and the services that they received from the U.S. government. The same study found [[civic engagement]] high among the population. While study participants felt like they generally were not welcomed throughout their community, they were accepted.<ref>Comer, J.C. (1978) "'Street-Level' Bureaucracy and Political Support: Some Findings on Mexican Americans," ''Urban Affairs Review, 14''(2). pp 207–227.</ref>
Between 1980 and 1990, the Latino population in the Midwest increased by 35.2%.<ref>Lopez, David A. (2000). [http://www.jsri.msu.edu/RandS/research/cb/cb12.html "Latinos in Omaha: An Examination of Socioeconomic Measures for Latinos in South Omaha."] ''Statistical Brief No. 12''. The Julian Samora Research Institute at Michigan State University.</ref> In 1990 Latinos accounted for 2.9% of the population of Omaha with the majority Mexican.<ref>Lopez, David A. (2000). [http://www.jsri.msu.edu/RandS/research/cb/cb12.html "Latinos in Omaha: An Examination of Socioeconomic Measures for Latinos in South Omaha."] ''Statistical Brief No. 12''. The Julian Samora Research Institute at Michigan State University.</ref>
Nebraska's Latino population nearly doubled from 1990 to 2005, largely due to increases in towns with meatpacking operations located within a two hundred mile radius of Omaha. While most of that population is Mexican, the numbers are not available.<ref>Bacon, D. (2005) [http://tapdev.browsermedia.com/cs/articles?article=and_the_winner_is_ "And the Winner Is... Immigration reform on the killing floor.] ''The American Prospect''. 10/23/05.</ref>
===Religion=== According to the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Omaha]], 74 percent of Mexicans and their American-born children in Omaha are Catholic. The streets of South Omaha, particularly the [[South Omaha Main Street Historic District]], are packed with religious celebrations throughout the year, including the Festival of the [[Virgin of Guadalupe]], the [[Day of the Dead]] and many other holidays in the Catholic religious calendar.<ref>Arbelaez, M. (2006) ''[http://www.unomaha.edu/ollas/pdf/Religion%20Report.pdf Religion and Community: Mexican Americans in South Omaha (1900–1980).]'' OLLAS Special Report No. 4. Omaha, NE: Office of Latino/Latin American Studies at the University of Nebraska at Omaha.</ref> According to another report, "Mexicans [in Omaha] celebrate Holy Week, one of the most important events in the Catholic liturgy, in remarkable public spectacles."<ref>Arbelaez, M. (2000) [http://www.eric.ed.gov/ERICWebPortal/custom/portlets/recordDetails/detailmini.jsp?_nfpb=true&_&ERICExtSearch_SearchValue_0=ED454016&ERICExtSearch_SearchType_0=eric_accno&accno=ED454016 "Good Friday in Omaha, Nebraska: A Mexican Celebration,"] in ''National Association of African American Studies & National Association of Hispanic and Latino Studies 2000 Literature Monograph Series.'' Proceedings (Culture Section) (Houston, TX, February 21–26, 2000). ERIC # ED454016. Retrieved 7/17/07.</ref>
===Culture=== Today South Omaha is also home to [[El Museo Latino]], located at 4701½ South 25th Street. Dedicated to Latino arts, the museum includes local, regional, national, and international exhibits. In addition to providing school tours and sponsoring a performing dance group, the museum features exhibits, family activities, art and cultural classes, and special events. It is a local repository for copies of the Omaha-related materials collected through the "Mexican American Traditions in Nebraska" project of the Nebraska State Historical Society.<ref>(1998) [http://www.nebraskahistory.org/lib-arch/whadoin/mexampub/resource.htm "Resource Guide"]. Nebraska State Historical Society. Retrieved 7/17/07.</ref> [[Nebraskans for Peace]] is another organization that seeks to advocate and assist Mexican Americans and Mexicans in Omaha.<ref>(nd) [http://www.nebraskansforpeace.org/history.php "History"], Nebraskans for Peace. Retrieved 7/17/07.</ref>
===Assimilation=== In the 1970s [[demographer]]s first starting noticing the reluctance of Omaha's Mexican-American population to [[Cultural assimilation|assimilate]] into [[American culture]].<ref>Comer, J. (1978) ""Street-Level" Bureaucracy and Political Support: Some Findings on Mexican Americans", ''Urban Affairs Review. 14''(2) p 207, 210-213, 225-227.</ref> Morality and values, food, language, and cultural ties have all been cited as important attributes of [[Mexican culture]] that recent immigrants and long-time Mexican Americans in Omaha, Nebraska want to maintain.<ref>Branigin, W. (1998) [http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/national/longterm/meltingpot/melt0525a.htm "Immigrants Shunning Idea of Assimilation,"] ''Washington Post''. 5/25/07. Retrieved 7/17/07.</ref> The lack of participation of Mexican-Americans in Omaha in the administration and [[Health care reform|reform]] of [[health care]] has also been noted as further evidence of the absence of desire to assimilate.<ref>Steinman, M. (1976) "Low-income and minority group representation in administrative processes: Mexican-American participation in health care services," ''Urban Affairs Quarterly. 11''(4) p 523-544.</ref>
Mexican-Americans have begun to exert political influence in Omaha. [[Spanish language|Spanish-language]] newspapers sold in Omaha include ''Nuestro Mundo'', ''El Perico'', ''La Vision Latina'', and ''El Sol de las Americas''.<ref>[http://www.mex-amer.state.ne.us/english/newsletter.html "Mexican America Commission."] Retrieved 9/1/07.</ref>
A [[Mexican diplomatic missions#North America|Mexican Consulate]] is located in Omaha at 3552 Dodge Street.<ref>[http://www.state.gov/s/cpr/rls/fco/21488.htm "Mexico"], United States Department of State. Retrieved 7/17/07.</ref><ref>[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/mx.html "Mexico"], [[CIA World Factbook]]. Retrieved 5/17/08.</ref> A 2007 [[neo-Nazi]] rally in Omaha drew 65 participants to a protest outside the consulate. Thousands were involved in counter-protests, as well as events celebrating the diversity of the city.<ref>Ruggles, R. and Cole, K. (2007) [http://www.omaha.com/index.php?u_page=2798&u_sid=10121747 "Huge police presence subdues Nazi rally"], ''[[Omaha World-Herald]]''. September 2, 2007. Retrieved 5/13/08.</ref>
==Notable Mexican Americans from Omaha== * [[Hector P. Garcia]] (January 17, 1914—July 26, 1996) - physician, surgeon, World War II veteran, civil rights advocate, and founder of the [[American G.I. Forum]]. He completed his residency at St. Joseph's Hospital at [[Creighton University]] in Omaha. * [[Edward Gomez]] (born August 10, 1932–September 14, 1951) - [[United States Marine]] who was [[Posthumous recognition|posthumously]] awarded the [[Medal of Honor]] during the [[Korean War]]. * [[Steve Turre]] (born September 12, 1948) - internationally renowned trombonist, recording artist, arranger, and educator born in Omaha. He is of Mexican descent. * [[John Trudell]] (born February 15, 1946) - author, a poet, musician and a former political activist who was born in Omaha. He is of Mexican descent. * [[Douglas Vincent "SA" Martinez]] (born October 29, 1969) - vocalist and DJ for the Los Angeles, California-based alternative rock band 311 born in Omaha.
